skill.name: Documentation Fundamentals
skill.description: Auto-invoke when reviewing README files, JSDoc comments, or inline documentation. Enforces "WHY not WHAT" principle.
skill.summary: Auto-invoke when reviewing README files, JSDoc comments, or inline documentation. Enforces "WHY not ...
skill.author: DanielPodolsky

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation guidelines. No executable code, network access, filesystem access, or command execution. Zero risk factors detected.

content.value_statement: Poor documentation wastes team time and creates confusion. This skill enforces documentation standards for README files, JSDoc comments, and inline code explanations following the WHY not WHAT principle. Get consistent, maintainable documentation that explains context and rationale, not redundant code descriptions.
actual_capabilities: Review and improve README files with the 5 essential sections
Write effective JSDoc comments with examples and edge cases
Create inline comments that explain WHY not WHAT
Identify documentation anti-patterns and fix them
Apply Socratic questions to improve documentation quality
Structure API documentation with parameters, returns, and examples
limitations: Does not generate documentation from code automatically
Does not validate documentation against external standards
Does not integrate with documentation hosting platforms
Provides guidelines only, not automated documentation tools

use_cases.title: Onboard with Clear READMEs
use_cases.description: New team members can run projects immediately with complete README documentation including installation and quick start steps.

use_cases.title: Create Contributor-Friendly Projects
use_cases.description: Attract contributors with clear installation instructions, contribution guidelines, and well-documented APIs.

use_cases.title: Enforce Team Documentation Standards
use_cases.description: Maintain consistent documentation across codebases with actionable review criteria and anti-pattern alerts.

prompt_templates.title: Review README
prompt_templates.scenario: Check if README has all required sections
prompt_templates.prompt: Review the README file for this project. Does it include these essential sections: What (one-sentence description), Why (problem solved), Installation, Quick Start, and Contributing? Point out any missing sections and suggest specific improvements.

prompt_templates.title: Improve Inline Comments
prompt_templates.prompt: Review the inline comments in this code. Flag any comments that just repeat what the code does (WHAT) and rewrite them to explain the context and rationale (WHY). Include the business reason or ticket reference where applicable.

prompt_templates.title: Write JSDoc
prompt_templates.prompt: Write complete JSDoc documentation for the exported functions in this file. Include: brief description, parameter descriptions with types, return value description, example usage, and any error conditions that may be thrown. Reference the function implementation to ensure accuracy.

prompt_templates.title: Audit Documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: Audit this codebase for documentation quality. Report: missing JSDoc on exported functions, outdated comments that contradict code, commented-out code that should be deleted, magic numbers without explanation, and empty or auto-generated READMEs that need expansion.

output_examples.input: Review the README and inline comments in my project
output: README Assessment: Missing 'Why' section explaining the problem this project solves
Inline comments needing improvement: Lines 24-26 (just repeats code), Lines 89-91 (outdated - says 'filter inactive' but code filters by role)
Missing JSDoc: 3 exported functions lack documentation
Good examples found: Lines 45-48 explain the rate limit headroom rationale

best_practices: Write comments that answer 'WHY' not 'WHAT' - the code already shows what happens
Include business context in comments - ticket numbers, stakeholder requirements, or edge case explanations
Keep READMEs up to date - a stale README is worse than no README
Use JSDoc for all exported functions - include examples showing correct usage
anti_patterns: Commenting obvious code like 'Set x to 5' or 'Loop through items'
Leaving commented-out code in the codebase - use git to recover old code
Writing documentation once and never updating it when code changes
Using magic numbers without explaining their meaning or origin

faq.question: What tools work with this skill?
faq.answer: Compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Use with any AI assistant that supports prompt-based skills.

faq.question: Does this generate documentation from code?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides guidelines and review criteria. It helps you write better documentation but does not auto-generate docs.

faq.question: How is this different from documentation generators?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on content quality and principles. It helps you write WHY-focused comments, not extract documentation from code signatures.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill contains only guidelines - no code execution, no network access, no file system access, no data collection.

faq.question: Why is the WHY not WHAT principle important?
faq.answer: Code shows WHAT happens. Comments should explain WHY it matters - business context, edge cases, decisions, and rationale the code cannot express.

faq.question: Can this help with API documentation?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill includes JSDoc templates with parameters, returns, throws, examples, and @see references for complete API docs.
